page.title: Application Names
page.p: The app element marks the human-readable name of an application or the title of a window within an application. It should not be used to mark the name of the command used to run an application; use cmd for this purpose instead.

item.p: The style attribute takes a space-seperated list of style hints. Processing tools should adjust their rendering according to those style hints they understand.
The app element can link to other pages or documents. See for more information.

section.title: Processing Expectations
section.p: Application names are usually nouns, and are often common words or phrases that are indicative of their functionality. Frequently, they are simply the name of what the application is. In English and many other languages, the use of an application name in a sentence may sound like the author has simply mistakenly omitted an article, if the application name is not understood to be a title.

For example, the calculator application that comes with Gnome is called Calculator. If an author were to write To start Calculator…, then a reader may confuse this for To start the calculator… with an error. This is even more pronounced in languages such as German where nouns are always capitalized.
For this reason, it is recommended that application names marked with the app element are rendered in italics or using some other font variation.

section.title: Comparison to DocBook
section.p: The app element is functionally similar to DocBook's application element.
